title: The Crusader: A cracking payout for customer who waited 6 months for new car window
text:
The Crusader: A cracking payout for customer who waited 6 months for new car window The Crusader: A cracking payout for customer who waited 6 months for new car window A £200 goodwill gesture has gone a long way to make amends for a driver’s cracked car windscreen which took close to six months to be replaced. PUBLISHED: 19:09, Sun, Oct 18, 2015 | UPDATED: 19:32, Sun, Oct 18, 2015 ALAMY Car windscreens are usually a straightforward job to repair 
Convertible car owner Christine Pearce was puzzled at first as to why such a straightforward job was proving so difficult but then when her patience started to run out, she asked Crusader to weigh in on her behalf a couple of weeks ago. 
A stone had scratched and cracked the car’s glass at the end of April. Christine, from west London, told us. “My insurance policy included windscreen cover and my claim was approved. So I got an appointment with the recommended windscreen repairer but then, instead of being job done, it was just the start of a long saga,” she explained. 
Her Mazda MX5 was less than two years old and the first fitter who arrived from Auto Windscreens had not brought along the right screen so he left saying he would need to source one from outside the UK. “When I was told the right type had arrived in mid-August I had to try several times to get another fitting date,” Christine added. “When I did get one, I waited at home but no one turned up.” 
Because the stone had damaged the screen on the passenger side, Christine could still drive her motor. “However the scratch was getting longer as time went on. I was told because the glass was laminated it would not break into pieces but I was not reassured.” GETTY Smashed car windows should be easy to claim on insurance 
Next she was promised a same-day appointment, only that also failed to materialise. “Then a pleasant young man arrived at my house without warning to do the fitting. However he had picked up the wrong windscreen,” she said. 
“When I complained to someone called Ashley at the company, I was pleased because someone did call me back but in September the whole pantomime resumed. I seem to be caught in a loop and am at my wits’ end wondering how to break it.” I seem to be caught in a loop and am at my wits’ end wondering how to break it Christine Pearce 
Fearing her windscreen had been allocated to another car and she was now back on a waiting list, Christine sent Crusader a concise catalogue of her woes. As this was the first problem we had ever received concerning Auto Windscreens, all the indications were Christine’s experience was not its normal standard of service. 
The company immediately had another go at fitting a screen but again to no avail. In the end it was Christine herself who came to the rescue by contacting the garage that originally supplied her car. It provided the part number and sourced the right model within a couple of days. 
Managing director of Auto Windscreens, Chris Thornton, made it clear there were no excuses for what had gone on but at least he had got to the bottom of why Christine had the problem. “We feel we have fallen short of expectations,” he said. Related articles Expensive recliner chair promised comfort but only brought pain 
“As an organisation we measure ourselves on our customer feedback and strive to deliver an excellent standard of care every time. 
“We have taken steps to investigate what has gone wrong for Mrs Pearce and this has uncovered a need for further training of our call handlers which will be actioned immediately. 
“We have awarded her £200 compensation to apologise and her £75 excess fee has been waived.” 
“At last I am a satisfied customer,” Christine cheered. 
“Thank you Crusader for all your help.” GETTY Christine had real trouble after her window got smashed Check if replacing part is cheaper 
IF your windscreen is damaged, check if your insurance covers it and whether claiming will affect any no-claims discount or your premium. It might be that paying for the replacement yourself will prove cheaper. 
If there are hold ups, find out the part number. This is not your job but it could save time. Always note the name of any customer services person you deal with. 
Technological advances, such as auto-dipping mirrors and GPS tracking systems are making windscreens more expensive so damage cover in insurance policies could disappear in future. GETTY Christine eventually found herself as a satisfied customer through Crusader's help 
Do you have a consumer problem or a tale of service that deserves applause? The Crusader is here to help. 
We can’t promise a reply but please write in with your full name and daytime phone number to: The Crusader, Daily Express, 10 Lower Thames Street, London EC3R 6EN or email us at crusader@express.co.uk.
